episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a variety of intriguing topics, including a persistent thundercloud in Australia, a Polish pilot's unexpected tennis match during WWII, the many things named after Mae West, and the surprising influence of Finnish death metal on language studies.

facts.fact: My fact this week is that for at least 80 years, the same thundercloud has been raining off the north coast of Australia. It's called Hector the Convector.

My fact is that during the Second World War, a Polish pilot was shot down over Southern England and he and his parachute landed in the grounds of a very respectable tennis club. He was immediately then signed in as a guest, offered a racket, lent some white flannels and thrashed his opponents until the RAF came to collect him.
Okay, my fact this week is that things named after Mae West include a soda bottle, a gas pump, a parachute malfunction, and a graph that explains the nuclear fission of uranium.
My fact this week is that in 2013, a survey revealed that 97% of students studying Finnish at Vienna University were mainly doing so because of their love for the country's death metal bands.
